there there's a uh um bailing
out. What you really don't want to be
doing is doing bailouts when it's it's
entirely problems that are idiosyncratic
to the industry. You can argue very much
that the the Chrysler bailout uh was uh
you know, this was this wasn't a problem
with the US economy. me it was a problem
with Chrysler and while it would have
been painful it probably would have been
better to let it go um much but but when
you're the reason why bailouts are a
thing to do right now is that we have
this aggregate problem it's hitting the
whole economy and we have a lot of
institutions that are in structural uh
in in structurally important positions
where they they're well Leman you know
you could have said actually on the day
after Lehman was allowed to fail There
were a lot of people a lot of uh
commentary particularly from people on
the conservative side talking about what
a great thing uh Pollson had done by
letting this you know letting the market
work showing that the um Uncle Sam won't
bail you out if you're doing bad
behavior and then it turned out that
Lehman's failure led to a paralysis of
of financial markets around the world
that it was too strategic. Um the other
thing I think you want to say is you you
know never you never want to bail out
the stockholders. The there you know
we're not in the business of protecting
people who made knowingly risky
investments namely equity from the
consequences of those investments going
bad. We are talking about keeping
necessary institutions in being but
we're not talking about uh making sure
that people don't lose money.
